story.text: (Updates to early afternoon)NEW YORK Jan 3 (Reuters) - U.S. stocks rallied on Wednesday -- the first trading day of 2007 -- as falling oil prices and news that Home Depot's (HD.N) embattled chief executive resigned spurred optimism among investors returning from a four-day break. Shares of Home Depot Inc. (HD.N) led gains, rising 3.1 percent to $41.40 and pushing the Dow Jones industrial average to a record high. The Nasdaq jumped more than 1 percent. "The indications early on were that we would get a nice rally and it was supported by some of the economic data this morning," said Paul Nolte, director of investments at Hinsdale Investments in Hinsdale, Illinois. "It's a combination of the oil off and the Home Depot news. I think the Home Depot news definitely lifted a cloud from around that stock." The Dow Jones industrial average .DJI was up 105.74 points, or 0.85 percent, at 12,568.89. The Standard & Poor's 500 Index .SPX was up 8.76 points, or 0.62 percent, at 1,427.06. The Nasdaq Composite Index .IXIC was up 33.80 points, or 1.40 percent, at 2,449.09. Home Depot Chief Executive Robert Nardelli, who came under fire last year for a pay package, left the retailer in a mutual decision with its board of directors.For details, see [ID:nN03383942] Oil prices fell 4.2 percent as mild weather in the U.S. Northeast cut demand for fuel in the world's biggest heating oil market. U.S. crude oil CLc1 fell $2.62 to $58.43 a barrel, sparking optimism that lower energy costs could help corporate profits. Adding support to the market, the Institute for Supply Management said its manufacturing index for December rose more than expected. The Dow earlier hit an all-time high of 12,580.35. U.S. stock markets were closed on Monday for the New Year's Day holiday and on Tuesday for a day of mourning for former U.S. President Gerald Ford.
story.title: us stocks - shares rise as oil falls , home depot jumps
